unnormalised: I remember when my friend, Priya Sharma, an aspiring fashion designer from NIFT Delhi, was distraught. She had created a unique saree design, incredibly intricate and reflecting the Madhubani art style. Priya displayed her designs at a small exhibition. Soon after, she saw a similar design being sold by a big brand, "Ethnic Vogue," at a much higher price. She was devastated; all her hard work seemed to have been copied without any acknowledgement or compensation.
normalised: I remember when my friend, Priya Sharma, an aspiring fashion designer from N-I-F-T Delhi, was distraught. She had created a unique saree design, incredibly intricate and reflecting the Madhubani art style. Priya displayed her designs at a small exhibition. Soon after, she saw a similar design being sold by a big brand, "Ethnic Vogue," at a much higher price. She was devastated; all her hard work seemed to have been copied without any acknowledgement or compensation.

unnormalised: She consulted Adv. R.K. Jain, who specializes in Intellectual Property (IP) law. He explained that although she hadn't formally registered her design, she likely had grounds for a legal claim under copyright law, especially since she had proof of prior creation dated 05/03/2023 (the date of her exhibition). However, he stressed the importance of documenting everything meticulously—photographs, sketches, exhibition invites—everything would be critical.
normalised: She consulted Advocate R. K. Jain, who specializes in Intellectual Property (I-P) law. He explained that although she hadn't formally registered her design, she likely had grounds for a legal claim under copyright law, especially since she had proof of prior creation dated fifth March two thousand and twenty three (the date of her exhibition). However, he stressed the importance of documenting everything meticulously—photographs, sketches, exhibition invites—everything would be critical.

unnormalised: The lawyer explained the nuances of design registration and how that could have provided stronger protection. He mentioned that if "Ethnic Vogue" had indeed copied her design, they could be liable for damages and an injunction preventing them from further sales of the infringing product. He advised her to send a legal notice to "Ethnic Vogue" through him.

unnormalised: Priya finally filed the case, seeking damages of ₹5,00,000. It was a long and taxing process, but eventually, she won. The court recognized her intellectual property rights and ruled in her favor, preventing "Ethnic Vogue" from selling the copied saree design. This whole experience really taught Priya and me the importance of IP rights and seeking expert advice early on; now, Priya is a huge advocate for design registration, and she even helps other young designers navigate the legal landscape!
